title: Malaria crisis looms as drug supplies run dry
description:
Medical charity Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) on Wednesday called for urgent action to secure and distribute life-saving malaria medications as South Sudan enters its peak malaria season.
The organization said nationwide stockouts caused by gaps in the regular supply system have left many health facilities without treatment for the past three months.
“Some MSF-supported sites have had no antimalarials or other essential medical supplies since May, severely undermining malaria prevention and care just as cases surge with the seasonal peak,” the group said in a statement.
Public health facilities in parts of Central Equatoria, Warrap, Northern Bahr el Ghazal and the Abyei Special Administrative Area have reportedly run out of antimalarial drugs. Facilities in Yei and Morobo counties have been without essential medicines since May, while ongoing violence and insecurity have further restricted access to health care.
As of late July, MSF said it had treated more than 44,000 patients in those areas, with numbers expected to rise sharply during the rainy season, which coincides with the malaria peak from July to November.
UNICEF began distributing remaining stockpiles of antimalarials earlier this month to cover 80 counties across all 10 states, but only 23 counties in Upper Nile, Jonglei and Unity states had received supplies as of mid-September. Those supplies are expected to last just one to two months.
Malaria remains the leading cause of illness and death in South Sudan, accounting for at least 30% of deaths, according to the World Health Organization. The WHO projects that malaria cases could reach 8.3 million in 2025 — a staggering figure for a country of 12 million people.
In 2024, public health services were stretched to the brink during the seasonal malaria surge. At Aweil State Hospital, for example, the pediatric ward was admitting up to 400 children per week in September — more than double the number from the previous year.
The hospital reported an average of 43 children admitted daily with severe malaria and 14 blood transfusions conducted each day. The facility was so overcrowded that some patients were treated in the corridors.
fullContent:
Medical charity Médecins Sans Frontières (Doctors Without Borders) on Wednesday called for urgent action to secure and distribute life-saving malaria medications as South Sudan enters its peak malaria season.
The organization said nationwide stockouts caused by gaps in the regular supply system have left many health facilities without treatment for the past three months.
“Some MSF-supported sites have had no antimalarials or other essential medical supplies since May, severely undermining malaria prevention and care just as cases surge with the seasonal peak,” the group said in a statement.
Public health facilities in parts of Central Equatoria, Warrap, Northern Bahr el Ghazal and the Abyei Special Administrative Area have reportedly run out of antimalarial drugs. Facilities in Yei and Morobo counties have been without essential medicines since May, while ongoing violence and insecurity have further restricted access to health care.
As of late July, MSF said it had treated more than 44,000 patients in those areas, with numbers expected to rise sharply during the rainy season, which coincides with the malaria peak from July to November.
UNICEF began distributing remaining stockpiles of antimalarials earlier this month to cover 80 counties across all 10 states, but only 23 counties in Upper Nile, Jonglei and Unity states had received supplies as of mid-September. Those supplies are expected to last just one to two months.
Malaria remains the leading cause of illness and death in South Sudan, accounting for at least 30% of deaths, according to the World Health Organization. The WHO projects that malaria cases could reach 8.3 million in 2025 — a staggering figure for a country of 12 million people.
In 2024, public health services were stretched to the brink during the seasonal malaria surge. At Aweil State Hospital, for example, the pediatric ward was admitting up to 400 children per week in September — more than double the number from the previous year.
The hospital reported an average of 43 children admitted daily with severe malaria and 14 blood transfusions conducted each day. The facility was so overcrowded that some patients were treated in the corridors.

fr.title: Une crise de la malaria se profile alors que les stocks de médicaments s'épuisent.
fr.description:
L'organisation humanitaire médicale Médecins Sans Frontières a appelé mercredi à une action urgente pour sécuriser et distribuer des médicaments antipaludiques vitaux alors que le Soudan du Sud entre dans sa saison de paludisme au plus fort de l'année. 

L'organisation a déclaré que des pénuries à l'échelle nationale, causées par des lacunes dans le système d'approvisionnement régulier, ont laissé de nombreux établissements de santé sans traitement depuis trois mois. 

« Certains sites soutenus par MSF n'ont pas reçu d'antipaludiques ni d'autres fournitures médicales essentielles depuis mai, ce qui compromet gravement la prévention et le traitement du paludisme au moment où les cas augmentent avec le pic saisonnier », a déclaré le groupe dans un communiqué. 

Les établissements de santé publics dans certaines parties de l'Équatoria centrale, de Warrap, du Bahr el Ghazal du Nord et de la zone administrative spéciale d'Abyei ont apparemment épuisé leurs stocks de médicaments antipaludiques. Les établissements des comtés de Yei et Morobo n'ont pas eu de médicaments essentiels depuis mai, tandis que la violence et l'insécurité en cours ont encore restreint l'accès aux soins de santé. 

Fin juillet, MSF a déclaré avoir traité plus de 44 000 patients dans ces zones, avec des chiffres qui devraient monter en flèche pendant la saison des pluies, qui coïncide avec le pic de paludisme de juillet à novembre. 

UNICEF a commencé à distribuer les stocks restants d'antipaludiques plus tôt ce mois-ci pour couvrir 80 comtés dans les 10 États, mais seuls 23 comtés des États du Nil Supérieur, de Jonglei et d'Unity avaient reçu des fournitures à la mi-septembre. Ces fournitures devraient durer seulement un à deux mois. 

Le paludisme reste la principale cause de maladie et de décès au Soudan du Sud, représentant au moins 30 % des décès, selon l'Organisation mondiale de la santé. L'OMS prévoit que les cas de paludisme pourraient atteindre 8,3 millions en 2025 — un chiffre ahurissant pour un pays de 12 millions d'habitants. 

En 2024, les services de santé publique étaient poussés à l'extrême pendant la montée saisonnière du paludisme. À l'hôpital de l'État d'Aweil, par exemple, le service pédiatrique accueillait jusqu'à 400 enfants par semaine en septembre — plus du double du nombre de l'année précédente. 

L'hôpital a rapporté une moyenne de 43 enfants admis quotidiennement pour paludisme sévère et 14 transfusions sanguines effectuées chaque jour. L'établissement était tellement surpeuplé que certains patients étaient traités dans les couloirs.

pt.title: Uma crise de malária se aproxima à medida que os suprimentos de medicamentos se esgotam.
pt.description:
A organização humanitária Médicos Sem Fronteiras (MSF) pediu na quarta-feira ação urgente para garantir e distribuir medicamentos essenciais para malária, à medida que o Sudão do Sul entra na sua temporada de pico da doença. A organização afirmou que a falta de estoques em todo o país, causada por lacunas no sistema de fornecimento regular, deixou muitas unidades de saúde sem tratamento nos últimos três meses. 

“Alguns locais apoiados pela MSF não têm antimaláricos ou outros suprimentos médicos essenciais desde maio, comprometendo severamente a prevenção e o tratamento da malária justo quando os casos aumentam com o pico sazonal”, disse o grupo em um comunicado. 

Unidades de saúde pública em partes de Equatória Central, Warrap, Bahr el Ghazal do Norte e na Área Administrativa Especial de Abyei relataram falta de medicamentos antimaláricos. As instalações nos condados de Yei e Morobo estão sem medicamentos essenciais desde maio, enquanto a violência e a insegurança em curso restringiram ainda mais o acesso aos cuidados de saúde. 

No final de julho, a MSF informou que tratou mais de 44.000 pacientes nessas áreas, com números que devem aumentar drasticamente durante a temporada de chuvas, que coincide com o pico da malária de julho a novembro. 

A UNICEF começou a distribuir os estoques restantes de antimaláricos no início deste mês para cobrir 80 condados em todos os 10 estados, mas apenas 23 condados nos estados de Alto Nilo, Jonglei e Unidade haviam recebido suprimentos até meados de setembro. Esses suprimentos devem durar apenas de um a dois meses. 

A malária continua sendo a principal causa de doença e morte no Sudão do Sul, representando pelo menos 30% das mortes, de acordo com a Organização Mundial da Saúde (OMS). A OMS projeta que os casos de malária podem atingir 8,3 milhões em 2025 — um número alarmante para um país com 12 milhões de habitantes. 

Em 2024, os serviços de saúde pública foram levados ao limite durante o aumento sazonal da malária. No Hospital Estadual de Aweil, por exemplo, a enfermaria pediátrica estava admitindo até 400 crianças por semana em setembro — mais do que o dobro do número do ano anterior. 

O hospital relatou uma média de 43 crianças admitidas diariamente com malária severa e 14 transfusões de sangue realizadas a cada dia. A instalação estava tão superlotada que alguns pacientes foram tratados nos corredores.

es.title: Se avecina una crisis de malaria a medida que se agotan los suministros de medicamentos.
es.description:
La organización benéfica médica Médicos Sin Fronteras (MSF) pidió el miércoles una acción urgente para asegurar y distribuir medicamentos antipalúdicos que salvan vidas, ya que Sudán del Sur entra en su temporada pico de malaria. 

La organización indicó que los desabastecimientos a nivel nacional, causados por fallas en el sistema de suministro regular, han dejado a muchas instalaciones de salud sin tratamientos durante los últimos tres meses. 

“Algunos sitios apoyados por MSF no han tenido antipalúdicos ni otros suministros médicos esenciales desde mayo, socavando gravemente la prevención y atención de la malaria justo cuando los casos aumentan con el pico estacional”, dijo el grupo en un comunicado. 

Las instalaciones de salud pública en partes de Equatoria Central, Warrap, Bahr el Ghazal del Norte y el Área Administrativa Especial de Abyei han informado que se han quedado sin medicamentos antipalúdicos. Las instalaciones en los condados de Yei y Morobo han estado sin medicamentos esenciales desde mayo, mientras que la violencia y la inseguridad en curso han restringido aún más el acceso a la atención médica. 

A finales de julio, MSF informó que había tratado a más de 44,000 pacientes en esas áreas, con números que se espera que aumenten drásticamente durante la temporada de lluvias, que coincide con el pico de malaria de julio a noviembre. 

UNICEF comenzó a distribuir los stock restantes de antipalúdicos a principios de este mes para cubrir 80 condados en los 10 estados, pero solo 23 condados en los estados de Nilo Superior, Jonglei y Unidad habían recibido suministros a mediados de septiembre. Se espera que esos suministros duren solo de uno a dos meses. 

La malaria sigue siendo la principal causa de enfermedad y muerte en Sudán del Sur, representando al menos el 30% de las muertes, según la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS). La OMS proyecta que los casos de malaria podrían alcanzar los 8.3 millones en 2025, una cifra asombrosa para un país de 12 millones de personas. 

En 2024, los servicios de salud pública estuvieron al borde durante el aumento estacional de la malaria. En el Hospital Estatal de Aweil, por ejemplo, la sala de pediatría estaba admitiendo hasta 400 niños por semana en septiembre, más del doble del número del año anterior. 

El hospital reportó un promedio de 43 niños admitidos diariamente con malaria severa y 14 transfusiones de sangre realizadas cada día. La instalación estaba tan abarrotada que algunos pacientes fueron tratados en los pasillos.

title: Rwanda: Inside Govt Plan to Curb Rising Malaria Cases
description: [New Times] Rwanda has recorded a resurgence of malaria after nearly six years of steady progress in reducing the disease. Between 2017 and 2023, cases had dropped by 90 percent, but infections have been climbing again since January 2024.
content: [New Times] Rwanda has recorded a resurgence of malaria after nearly six years of steady progress in reducing the disease. Between 2017 and 2023, cases had dropped by 90 percent, but infections have been climbing again since January 2024.

title: Authorities again warn of vector-borne ailments
description: KARACHI: Authorities on Tuesday again warned that outbreaks of water and vector-borne diseases such as dengue that may spread rapidly across the country. The danger is particularly acute in areas devastated by floods, where stagnant water and poor sanitation are creating conditions ripe for epidemics.Health officials said overcrowded shelters, shortage of clean drinking water, and disruption of healthcare services are increasing the risk of cholera, gastroenteritis, malaria, and dengue. Emergency teams have been asked to step up medical surveillance and preventive measures in affected regions.The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) Sindh reported that the Indus River remains in dangerous flood condition, with high levels at Guddu and Sukkur barrages. Water inflows at Kotri barrage are also being closely monitored as pressure builds downstream.Rescue and relief operations are continuing, but authorities stressed that public cooperation is vital. People living near embankments have been advised to shift to safer areas, while mobile health units are being prepared to provide treatment in case of sudden outbreaks.The PDMA said no major weather system is expected, though scattered thunderstorms and moderate rains are likely over the upper catchments of rivers and in parts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, and Islamabad until September 19. Officials have been directed to remain alert against the risk of further flooding.At the same time, the Climate Change Impact and Integration Cell of the Pakistan Meteorological Department issued a dengue alert, warning that floodwater stagnation, combined with prevailing temperature and humidity, has created conditions for a severe outbreak.The high-risk period is expected to begin from September 20, with Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Rawalpindi, Peshawar, Sukkur, Hyderabad, and Multan identified as danger zones. Health authorities have been instructed to intensify fumigation, clear drainage systems, and link anti-dengue measures with ongoing flood relief efforts. Citizens have been urged to remove standing water, use repellents, and take precautions against mosquito bites.Copyright Business Recorder, 2025

en.title: Authorities again warn of vector-borne diseases.
en.description: KARACHI: Authorities on Tuesday again warned that outbreaks of water and vector-borne diseases such as dengue may spread rapidly across the country. The danger is particularly acute in areas devastated by floods, where stagnant water and poor sanitation are creating conditions ripe for epidemics. Health officials said overcrowded shelters, shortage of clean drinking water, and disruption of healthcare services are increasing the risk of cholera, gastroenteritis, malaria, and dengue. Emergency teams have been asked to step up medical surveillance and preventive measures in affected regions. The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) Sindh reported that the Indus River remains in dangerous flood condition, with high levels at Guddu and Sukkur barrages. Water inflows at Kotri barrage are also being closely monitored as pressure builds downstream. Rescue and relief operations are continuing, but authorities stressed that public cooperation is vital. People living near embankments have been advised to shift to safer areas, while mobile health units are being prepared to provide treatment in case of sudden outbreaks. The PDMA said no major weather system is expected, though scattered thunderstorms and moderate rains are likely over the upper catchments of rivers and in parts of Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab, and Islamabad until September 19. Officials have been directed to remain alert against the risk of further flooding. At the same time, the Climate Change Impact and Integration Cell of the Pakistan Meteorological Department issued a dengue alert, warning that floodwater stagnation, combined with prevailing temperature and humidity, has created conditions for a severe outbreak. The high-risk period is expected to begin from September 20, with Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Rawalpindi, Peshawar, Sukkur, Hyderabad, and Multan identified as danger zones. Health authorities have been instructed to intensify fumigation, clear drainage systems, and link anti-dengue measures with ongoing flood relief efforts. Citizens have been urged to remove standing water, use repellents, and take precautions against mosquito bites. Copyright Business Recorder, 2025.

fr.title: Les autorités mettent à nouveau en garde contre les maladies vectorielles.
fr.description:
KARACHI : Les autorités ont de nouveau averti mardi que des épidémies de maladies d'origine hydrique et véctorielle telles que la dengue pourraient se propager rapidement à travers le pays. Le danger est particulièrement aigu dans les zones dévastées par les inondations, où l'eau stagnante et l'assainissement médiocre créent des conditions propices aux épidémies. Les responsables de la santé ont déclaré que l'engorgement des abris, le manque d'eau potable et la disruption des services de santé augmentent le risque de choléra, de gastro-entérite, de paludisme et de dengue. Les équipes d'urgence ont été invitées à intensifier la surveillance médicale et les mesures préventives dans les régions touchées. 

L'Autorité provinciale de gestion des catastrophes (PDMA) du Sindh a rapporté que le fleuve Indus reste en condition d'inondation dangereuse, avec des niveaux élevés aux barrages de Guddu et de Sukkur. Les apports en eau au barrage de Kotri sont également surveillés de près alors que la pression monte en aval. Les opérations de sauvetage et de secours se poursuivent, mais les autorités ont insisté sur le fait que la coopération du public est vitale. Les personnes vivant près des digues ont été conseillées de se déplacer vers des zones plus sûres, tandis que des unités de santé mobiles sont préparées pour fournir des traitements en cas d'épidémies soudaines. 

La PDMA a déclaré qu'aucun système météorologique majeur n'est prévu, bien que des orages dispersés et des pluies modérées soient probables sur les bassins supérieurs des rivières et dans certaines parties de Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, du Pendjab et d'Islamabad jusqu'au 19 septembre. Les responsables ont été instruits de rester vigilants face au risque d'inondations supplémentaires. 

Simultanément, le Cellule de l'impact et de l'intégration du changement climatique du Département météorologique du Pakistan a émis une alerte dengue, avertissant que la stagnation des eaux d'inondation, combinée aux températures et à l'humidité actuelles, a créé des conditions propices à une épidémie sévère. La période à haut risque devrait commencer à partir du 20 septembre, avec Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Rawalpindi, Peshawar, Sukkur, Hyderabad et Multan identifiés comme zones dangereuses. Les autorités sanitaires ont été chargées d'intensifier la fumigation, de nettoyer les systèmes de drainage et de relier les mesures anti-dengue aux efforts de secours en cours liés aux inondations. Les citoyens ont été exhortés à éliminer l'eau stagnante, à utiliser des répulsifs et à prendre des précautions contre les piqûres de moustiques. 

Copyright Business Recorder, 2025

pt.title: As autoridades alertam novamente sobre doenças transmitidas por vetores.
pt.description: KARACHI: As autoridades alertaram na terça-feira que surtos de doenças transmitidas pela água e por vetores, como a dengue, podem se espalhar rapidamente pelo país. O perigo é particularmente agudo em áreas devastadas por inundações, onde a água parada e o saneamento precário estão criando condições propícias para epidemias. Funcionários de saúde afirmaram que abrigos superlotados, escassez de água potável e a interrupção dos serviços de saúde estão aumentando o risco de cólera, gastroenterite, malária e dengue. Equipes de emergência foram convocadas a intensificar a vigilância médica e as medidas preventivas nas regiões afetadas. A Autoridade Provincial de Gestão de Desastres (PDMA) de Sindh relatou que o rio Indus continua em condição de inundação perigosa, com níveis altos nas barragens de Guddu e Sukkur. Os fluxos de água na barragem de Kotri também estão sendo monitorados de perto à medida que a pressão aumenta a jusante. As operações de resgate e alívio continuam, mas as autoridades enfatizaram que a cooperação pública é vital. As pessoas que vivem próximas às margens foram aconselhadas a se mudar para áreas mais seguras, enquanto unidades de saúde móveis estão sendo preparadas para fornecer tratamento em caso de surtos repentinos. A PDMA disse que nenhum sistema meteorológico significativo é esperado, embora tempestades esparsas e chuvas moderadas sejam prováveis nas áreas superiores das bacias dos rios e em partes de Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab e Islamabad até 19 de setembro. Os funcionários foram orientados a permanecerem alertas quanto ao risco de novas inundações. Ao mesmo tempo, o Centro de Impacto e Integração das Mudanças Climáticas do Departamento Meteorológico do Paquistão emitiu um alerta de dengue, avisando que a estagnação das águas das inundações, combinada com a temperatura e umidade predominantes, criou condições para um surto severo. O período de alto risco deve começar em 20 de setembro, com Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Rawalpindi, Peshawar, Sukkur, Hyderabad e Multan identificados como zonas de perigo. As autoridades de saúde foram instruídas a intensificar a fumigação, limpar os sistemas de drenagem e vincular as medidas anti-dengue aos esforços de alívio das inundações em andamento. Os cidadãos foram instados a remover água parada, usar repelentes e tomar precauções contra picadas de mosquito. Direitos Autorais Business Recorder, 2025.

es.title: Las autoridades advierten nuevamente sobre enfermedades transmitidas por vectores.
es.description:
KARACHI: Las autoridades advirtieron el martes que los brotes de enfermedades transmitidas por el agua y vectores, como el dengue, podrían propagarse rápidamente por todo el país. El peligro es particularmente agudo en áreas devastadas por inundaciones, donde el agua estancada y la mala sanidad están creando condiciones propicias para epidemias. Los funcionarios de salud dijeron que los refugios abarrotados, la escasez de agua potable y la interrupción de los servicios de salud están aumentando el riesgo de cólera, gastroenteritis, malaria y dengue. Se ha solicitado a los equipos de emergencia que intensifiquen la vigilancia médica y las medidas preventivas en las regiones afectadas. 

La Autoridad Provincial de Manejo de Desastres (PDMA) de Sindh informó que el río Indo sigue en condiciones de inundación peligrosas, con altos niveles en las compuertas de Guddu y Sukkur. Los flujos de agua en la compuerta de Kotri también están siendo monitoreados de cerca a medida que aumenta la presión río abajo. Las operaciones de rescate y ayuda continúan, pero las autoridades enfatizaron que la cooperación pública es vital. Se ha aconsejado a las personas que viven cerca de los diques que se trasladen a áreas más seguras, mientras que se están preparando unidades de salud móviles para proporcionar tratamiento en caso de brotes repentinos. 

La PDMA dijo que no se espera ningún sistema meteorológico importante, aunque es probable que haya tormentas dispersas y lluvias moderadas en las cuencas superiores de los ríos y en partes de Khyber Pakhtunkhwa, Punjab e Islamabad hasta el 19 de septiembre. Se ha instruido a los funcionarios que permanezcan alertas ante el riesgo de nuevas inundaciones. Al mismo tiempo, el Centro de Impacto e Integración del Cambio Climático del Departamento Meteorológico de Pakistán emitió una alerta de dengue, advirtiendo que la estancación de aguas de inundación, combinada con la temperatura y humedad actuales, ha creado condiciones para un brote severo. 

Se espera que el período de alto riesgo comience el 20 de septiembre, con Karachi, Lahore, Islamabad, Faisalabad, Sialkot, Rawalpindi, Peshawar, Sukkur, Hyderabad y Multan identificados como zonas de peligro. Se ha instruido a las autoridades de salud que intensifiquen la fumigación, limpien los sistemas de drenaje y vinculen las medidas contra el dengue con los esfuerzos de ayuda por inundaciones en curso. Se ha instado a los ciudadanos a eliminar el agua estancada, usar repelentes y tomar precauciones contra las picaduras de mosquitos. 

Derechos de autor Business Recorder, 2025.

title: Korea's visa-free policy for Chinese tour groups incites public anger
description: Korea’s visa-free entry program for Chinese tour groups is drawing public backlash, with more than 52,000 citizens signing a petition for its cancellation just two weeks before it is set to begin. The public backlash, amid an undercurrent of rising anti-China sentiment, is being fueled by a mix of historical grievances, economic competition and a nationalist reaction to what's perceived by many Koreans as Beijing's assertive cultural and political influence in the region. Scheduled to run from Sept. 29 through next June, the visa-free initiative has drawn criticism amid growing concerns over safety and potential abuse. Petitioners cite a mosquito-borne viral outbreak in China’s Guangdong Province, which has recorded more than 10,000 cases, warning that increased travel could threaten public health. They note that infected mosquitoes can be carried by airplanes — a phenomenon known as “airport malaria,” or more broadly, “airport-borne vector transmission,” a recognized public health risk. “The government, which is responsible for the health of its people, should immediate

en.title: Korea's visa-free policy for Chinese tour groups incites public anger
en.description: ly reconsider the visa-free entry program,” said one petitioner. “We cannot ignore the potential health risks that come with allowing large groups of tourists from regions experiencing viral outbreaks.” The visa-free policy was initially aimed at boosting tourism and economic ties with China, but the public sentiment has shifted dramatically as safety concerns take precedence. Many citizens are calling for stricter health and safety protocols to be implemented for any incoming tourists, regardless of nationality, to protect the well-being of the local population. As the start date approaches, the government is faced with the challenge of addressing these concerns while trying to maintain economic relations with China.

fr.title: La politique de visa sans frais de la Corée pour les groupes de tourisme chinois suscite la colère du public.
fr.description: Le programme d'entrée sans visa de la Corée pour les groupes de touristes chinois suscite une réaction négative du public, avec plus de 52 000 citoyens signant une pétition pour son annulation juste deux semaines avant son lancement prévu. Cette réaction est alimentée par un mélange de griefs historiques, de concurrence économique et d'une réaction nationaliste face à ce que beaucoup de Coréens perçoivent comme l'influence culturelle et politique assertive de Pékin dans la région, dans un contexte de sentiment anti-chinois croissant. Prévu pour se dérouler du 29 septembre jusqu'en juin prochain, l'initiative sans visa a attiré des critiques au milieu de préoccupations grandissantes concernant la sécurité et les abus potentiels. Les pétitionnaires évoquent une épidémie virale transmise par les moustiques dans la province du Guangdong en Chine, qui a enregistré plus de 10 000 cas, avertissant que l'augmentation des voyages pourrait menacer la santé publique. Ils notent que des moustiques infectés peuvent être transportés par des avions — un phénomène connu sous le nom de « malaria aéroportuaire », ou plus largement, de « transmission vectorielle aéroportuaire », un risque reconnu pour la santé publique. « Le gouvernement, qui est responsable de la santé de son peuple, devrait immédiatement... »

pt.title: A política de isenção de visto da Coreia para grupos de turistas chineses provoca raiva pública.
pt.description: O programa de entrada sem visto da Coreia para grupos de turistas chineses está gerando uma reação pública negativa, com mais de 52.000 cidadãos assinando uma petição pela sua cancelamento apenas duas semanas antes de sua implementação. A reação negativa do público, em meio a um subtexto de crescente sentimento anti-China, é alimentada por uma mistura de queixas históricas, competição econômica e uma reação nacionalista ao que muitos coreanos percebem como a influência cultural e política assertiva de Pequim na região. Programada para ocorrer de 29 de setembro até o próximo junho, a iniciativa sem visto tem recebido críticas em meio a crescentes preocupações com a segurança e o potencial abuso. Os peticionários citam um surto viral transmitido por mosquitos na província de Guangdong, na China, que registrou mais de 10.000 casos, alertando que o aumento das viagens poderia ameaçar a saúde pública. Eles observam que mosquitos infectados podem ser transportados por aviões — um fenômeno conhecido como “malária de aeroporto”, ou mais amplamente, “transmissão de vetores de aeroporto”, um risco reconhecido à saúde pública. “O governo, que é responsável pela saúde de seu povo, deve imediatamente...

es.title: La política de exención de visa de Corea para grupos de turistas chinos genera ira pública.
es.description: El programa de entrada sin visa de Corea para grupos turísticos chinos está generando reacciones negativas en la opinión pública, con más de 52,000 ciudadanos firmando una petición para su cancelación justo dos semanas antes de que comience. La reacción pública, en medio de un trasfondo de creciente sentimiento anti-China, se ve alimentada por una mezcla de agravios históricos, competencia económica y una reacción nacionalista ante lo que muchos coreanos perciben como la asertiva influencia cultural y política de Beijing en la región. Programada para llevarse a cabo desde el 29 de septiembre hasta el próximo junio, la iniciativa de entrada sin visa ha sido objeto de críticas en medio de crecientes preocupaciones sobre la seguridad y el posible abuso. Los peticionarios citan un brote viral transmitido por mosquitos en la provincia china de Guangdong, que ha registrado más de 10,000 casos, advirtiendo que un aumento en los viajes podría amenazar la salud pública. Señalan que los mosquitos infectados pueden ser transportados por aviones —un fenómeno conocido como “malaria aeroportuaria”, o más ampliamente, “transmisión de vectores aeroportuarios”, un riesgo reconocido para la salud pública. “El gobierno, que es responsable de la salud de su pueblo, debería actuar de inmediato.

title: Sirsa launches drive against mosquito-borne diseases
description: A District Malaria Control Committee meeting reviewed plans to combat dengue and malaria. A special campaign starts September 25th, with fines for mosquito larvae. Departments must clean water containers weekly. Schools should educate children, who will share information with families. Anganwadi workers will provide door-to-door education.

fr.title: Sirsa lance une campagne contre les maladies transmises par les moustiques.
fr.description: Une réunion du Comité de Contrôle du Paludisme de District a examiné les plans pour lutter contre la dengue et le paludisme. Une campagne spéciale commence le 25 septembre, avec des amendes pour les larves de moustiques. Les départements doivent nettoyer les réservoirs d'eau chaque semaine. Les écoles devraient éduquer les enfants, qui partageront les informations avec leurs familles. Les travailleurs Anganwadi fourniront une éducation porte-à-porte.

pt.title: Sirsa inicia campanha contra doenças transmitidas por mosquitos.

Uma campanha especial começa no dia 25 de setembro, com multas para larvas de mosquito. Os departamentos devem limpar os recipientes de água semanalmente. As escolas devem educar as crianças, que compartilharão informações com as famílias. Os trabalhadores do Anganwadi fornecerão educação de porta em porta.

es.title: Sirsa lanza campaña contra enfermedades transmitidas por mosquitos.

Una campaña especial comienza el 25 de septiembre, con multas por larvas de mosquito. Los departamentos deben limpiar los recipientes de agua semanalmente. Las escuelas deben educar a los niños, quienes compartirán información con sus familias. Los trabajadores de Anganwadi proporcionarán educación de puerta a puerta.

title: DNA from our ancient Denisovan ancestors may protect us from some tropical diseases
description: Malaria is one of the world's most widespread and deadliest parasitic diseases. But some people may have natural protection thanks to DNA inherited from an extinct group of archaic humans known as the Denisovans. New research has looked at specific Denisovan-derived genes that may protect against this and other tropical diseases.
content: Malaria is one of the world's most widespread and deadliest parasitic diseases. But some people may have natural protection thanks to DNA inherited from an extinct group of archaic humans known as the Denisovans. New research has looked at specific D... [2835 chars]

fr.title: L'ADN de nos anciens ancêtres Denisoviens pourrait nous protéger de certaines maladies tropicales.
fr.description: Le paludisme est l'une des maladies parasitaires les plus répandues et les plus meurtrières au monde. Mais certaines personnes peuvent bénéficier d'une protection naturelle grâce à l'ADN hérité d'un groupe éteint d'humains archaïques connu sous le nom de Denisoviens. De nouvelles recherches se sont intéressées à des gènes spécifiques dérivés des Denisoviens qui pourraient protéger contre cette maladie et d'autres maladies tropicales.

pt.title: O DNA de nossos antigos ancestrais denisovanos pode nos proteger de algumas doenças tropicais.
pt.description: A malária é uma das doenças parasitárias mais disseminadas e mortais do mundo. No entanto, algumas pessoas podem ter proteção natural graças ao DNA herdado de um grupo extinto de humanos arcaicos conhecidos como Denisovanos. Novas pesquisas analisaram genes específicos derivados dos Denisovanos que podem oferecer proteção contra essa e outras doenças tropicais.

es.title: El ADN de nuestros antiguos ancestros denisovanos puede protegernos de algunas enfermedades tropicales.
es.description: La malaria es una de las enfermedades parasitarias más extendidas y mortales del mundo. Sin embargo, algunas personas pueden tener protección natural gracias a un ADN heredado de un grupo extinto de humanos arcaicos conocido como los Denisovanos. Nueva investigación ha examinado genes específicos derivados de los Denisovanos que pueden proteger contra esta y otras enfermedades tropicales.

title: Alerta en Bolívar por detección de nueva especie de mosquito transmisor de la malaria

title: Delhi sees record rise in malaria cases; AAP demands urgent action from BJP govt
description: Citing the MCD’s latest weekly report, the MCD LoP said that malaria has broken a five-year record, with 33 fresh cases reported in just the past week.
content: With malaria, dengue, and chikungunya cases on the rise in the capital, Aam Aadmi Party’s Leader of Opposition (LoP) in the Municipal Corporation of Delhi (MCD), Ankush Narang, lashed out at the BJP government and accused it of turning a blind eye to... [1290 chars]

fr.title: Delhi enregistre une augmentation record des cas de paludisme ; AAP demande une action urgente du gouvernement BJP.
fr.description: Citant le dernier rapport hebdomadaire du MCD, le LoP du MCD a déclaré que le paludisme a atteint un record de cinq ans, avec 33 nouveaux cas signalés rien que la semaine dernière.

pt.title: Nova Délhi registra aumento recorde nos casos de malária; AAP exige ação urgente do governo do BJP.
pt.description: Citando o último relatório semanal do MCD, o LoP do MCD disse que a malária quebrou um recorde de cinco anos, com 33 novos casos reportados apenas na última semana.

es.title: Delhi registra un aumento récord en los casos de malaria; AAP exige acción urgente del gobierno de BJP.
es.description: Citando el último informe semanal del MCD, el LoP del MCD dijo que la malaria ha roto un récord de cinco años, con 33 nuevos casos reportados solo en la última semana.

title: Fogging In Jammu As Threat Of Dengue, Malaria Looms
description: JAMMU, Sept 16: While the cleanliness and sanitation drive post-floods is in full swing, fogging has also been intensified in all municipal and non-municipal areas as threat of dengue and malaria loom in the affected areas of Jammu. The Jammu Municipal Corporation and State Malarialogist Office of Jammu Health Department have jointly initiated the exercise of fogging and spraying in the flood-affected areas to control the rise in the water-borne and vector-borne diseases. Dhruv Ji Raina, Malariologist, Jammu Health department […]
content:
JAMMU, Sept 16: While the cleanliness and sanitation drive post-floods is in full swing, fogging has also been intensified in all municipal and non-municipal areas as threat of dengue and malaria loom in the affected areas of Jammu.
The Jammu Municip... [3634 chars]

fr.title: Brouillard à Jammu alors que la menace de la dengue et du paludisme plane.
fr.description: JAMMU, 16 sept : Alors que la campagne de propreté et d'assainissement après les inondations est en plein essor, la lutte contre les moustiques a également été intensifiée dans toutes les zones municipales et non municipales en raison de la menace de dengue et de paludisme qui plane sur les zones touchées de Jammu. La Municipalité de Jammu et le Bureau des Malarialogistes du Département de la Santé de Jammu ont conjointement lancé l'opération de lutte anti-moustiques et de pulvérisation dans les zones touchées par les inondations pour contrôler l'augmentation des maladies d'origine hydrique et transmises par des vecteurs. Dhruv Ji Raina, Malarialogiste, Département de la Santé de Jammu [...]

pt.title: Fumos em Jammu À Medida Que A Ameaça de Dengue e Malária Se Aproxima
pt.description: JAMMU, 16 de setembro: Enquanto a campanha de limpeza e saneamento após as enchentes está a todo vapor, a nebulização também foi intensificada em todas as áreas municipais e não municipais, já que a ameaça de dengue e malária paira nas áreas afetadas de Jammu. A Corporação Municipal de Jammu e o Escritório de Malarilogista do Departamento de Saúde de Jammu iniciaram em conjunto o exercício de nebulização e pulverização nas áreas afetadas pelas enchentes para controlar o aumento das doenças transmitidas por água e vetores. Dhruv Ji Raina, Malarilogista, Departamento de Saúde de Jammu […]

es.title: Nebulización en Jammu ante la amenaza de dengue y malaria.
es.description: JAMMU, 16 de septiembre: Mientras la campaña de limpieza y saneamiento tras las inundaciones está en pleno apogeo, la fumigación también se ha intensificado en todas las áreas municipales y no municipales, ya que la amenaza de dengue y malaria se cierne sobre las áreas afectadas de Jammu. La Corporación Municipal de Jammu y la Oficina del Malariólogo Estatal del Departamento de Salud de Jammu han iniciado conjuntamente el ejercicio de fumigación y rociado en las áreas afectadas por las inundaciones para controlar el aumento de enfermedades transmitidas por el agua y por vectores. Dhruv Ji Raina, Malariólogo, Departamento de Salud de Jammu […]

title: They’re tiny, they’re everywhere — and they have a huge impact on public health
description:
They can’t be seen with the naked eye, but microorganisms are all around us. While most are harmless and some are beneficial, others can make us sick.
September 17 is International Microorganism Day, marking the day in 1683 when Dutch scientist Antonie van Leeuwenhoek sent a letter detailing the first microscopic observation of a single-celled organism we now call bacteria. The letter described “living animalcules” that van Leeuwenhoek gathered from his own mouth and those of others.
To commemorate the day, we’re highlighting three Clemson University College of Science faculty members whose research involves microorganisms.
Most humans inhale fungal spores daily. People with healthy immune systems can clear the spores without any problems, but those who are immunocompromised are susceptible to infection.
Emily Rosowski, an assistant professor in the Department of Biological Sciences, studies microbes with pathogenic potential in immunocompromised people. These people could have a genetic deficiency or take immunosuppressive drugs, such as transplant patients who take medication so their immune system does not attack and reject the new organ.
These types of infections are called opportunistic infections. Rosowski focuses explicitly on aspergillosis, the disease caused by the fungus Aspergillus fumigatus. Aspergillus fumigatus lives in our environment just about anywhere, mainly in the soil, and functions as a decomposer. The microorganism produces spores during its reproductive life cycle stage.
Rosowski’s research focuses on understanding the immune system’s first line of defense against these spores to determine what goes wrong in immunocompromised individuals. When people are infected, Rosowski says, “these small spores germinate into hyphae, which is a filamentous growth. That growth secretes enzymes that degrade your tissues so it can grow throughout your tissues and through all your body.”
There are antifungal drugs that can stem infection, but 50% of patients who take these drugs still die from the disease.
Rosowski uses zebrafish in the larval form to visualize via microscope what’s happening in the early stages of infection and how specific cells in the immune system react to the fungus. Rosowski and her team have found a particular receptor called Toll-like Receptor 2 that helps the immune system recognize and target the spores.
“The long-term goal is to identify the key pathways that your healthy innate immune system uses to control the fungus and then think about ways you could try to boost those pathways in immunosuppressed people,” Rosowski says.
Rosowski’s work has the potential to lead to a treatment that would prevent infections from taking hold in immunocompromised individuals.
Splash pads and pools are popular attractions in the summer as people seek to keep cool in the scorching heat. But that water can bring something other than relief from high temperatures.
Cryptosporidium is a parasitic microorganism that causes diarrheal disease and can linger in water for over a week. More surprisingly, it is resistant to chlorine.
Katelyn Walzer, an assistant professor in the Department of Biological, studies Cryptosporidium — specifically Cryptosporidium parvum, which infects cattle and humans. About 70% of 1- to 3-week-old calves are infected with Cryptosporidium. The infection usually spreads in cattle through fecal to oral transmission.
In humans, the parasite poses the most risks to malnourished children and the immunocompromised.
Historically, cryptosporidiosis has been an understudied disease. It is usually underreported since most instances do not require hospitalization. Most cases requiring medical intervention occur in developing countries that do not always have access to clean water.
The parasite can lead to malabsorption of nutrients, which stunts growth and leads to the inability to fully heal from the infection.
The parasite goes through a dormant form called an oocyst, forming a resilient wall that allows it to persist in water without a host. Humans need to ingest only 10 oocysts to become ill, but a single diarrheal episode could excrete millions.
When the parasite changes to its active form, it infects its host’s gut and goes through sexual reproduction. The process of the parasites’ becoming male or female is essential to its propagation in the host. Walzer is researching how the parasites switch from asexual to male or female by looking at which genes activate during different points of the parasite’s life cycle.
Walzer identified a transcription factor, Myb-M, that, when removed from Cryptosporidium, stops parasites from becoming male. When Myb-M is removed from Cryptosporidium-infected mice, the infection subsides.
“We can use sex in this parasite as a transmission blocking strategy and also as a continuous infection blocking strategy,” Walzer says.
Around two-thirds of the global population is at risk of contracting malaria because they live in areas where the disease can be transmitted by mosquitoes.
Health organizations estimate that malaria causes 600,000 deaths annually, mostly among children. Medicines exist but resistance against all antimalarials is reported globally, and the currently available vaccine provides only about 30% to 60% protection.
Manuel Fierro, an assistant professor in the Department of Genetics and Biochemistry, studies the cell biology of the microorganism that causes malaria. Malaria is caused by a single-cell eukaryotic parasite that invades other cells.
Fierro investigates the different biological pathways necessary for the parasite’s survival.
Malaria has developed resistance to every anti-malarial drug. With six different species of malaria that can infect humans, each geographic area responds differently to medicines.
“That’s why my type of research is important to continue increasing knowledge about malaria and which biological pathways or proteins are critical for its survival. That can then inform the rest of the community, and it could result in another much needed anti-malarial,” Fierro says.
Malaria infection and symptoms come from the microorganism invading the body and breaking red blood cells open. Fierro studies the active portion of the malaria life cycle, focusing on the deadliest species, Plasmodium falciparum. He uses human blood to culture the parasite and different molecular approaches to visualize proteins and discover their importance.
Malaria is a haploid organism, meaning it has one only copy of each gene in each cell. That means traditional knockout methods of removing one copy of genes are not viable. Fierro has instead developed processes to tune down the expression of a gene instead of entirely knocking it out.
To survive within the host’s body, malaria must remake the red blood cell it has invaded, programming it to bring nutrients to the parasite. It exports and sends hundreds of proteins to the red blood cell to modify the cell. While researchers have determined the key players involved in protein transport from malaria parasites to the red blood cell, there is a gap in knowledge about which compounds can hit these proteins and disable the parasite.
“Currently my group is trying to develop sensitive assays to measure protein export. The current methods we have to measure export take a long time, and our approach would be quicker and more reliable,” Fierro says. This assay could lead to large-scale screening to determine what compounds inhibit malaria’s ability to survive within a human host, which could have future treatment implications.

fr.title: Ils sont minuscules, ils sont partout — et ils ont un énorme impact sur la santé publique.
fr.description:
Ils ne peuvent pas être vus à l'œil nu, mais les microorganismes sont tout autour de nous. Alors que la plupart sont inoffensifs et que certains sont bénéfiques, d'autres peuvent nous rendre malades. 
Le 17 septembre est la Journée internationale des microorganismes, marquant le jour en 1683 où le scientifique néerlandais Antonie van Leeuwenhoek a envoyé une lettre détaillant la première observation microscopique d'un organisme unicellulaire que nous appelons maintenant bactéries. La lettre décrivait des "animalcules vivants" que van Leeuwenhoek avait prélevés dans sa propre bouche et celles d'autres personnes. 
Pour commémorer cette journée, nous mettons en avant trois membres du corps professoral de la College of Science de l'Université de Clemson dont la recherche implique des microorganismes. 
La plupart des humains inhalent quotidiennement des spores fongiques. Les personnes ayant un système immunitaire sain peuvent éliminer les spores sans problème, mais celles qui sont immunodéprimées sont susceptibles de contracter une infection. 
Emily Rosowski, professeure adjointe au Département des sciences biologiques, étudie les microbes ayant un potentiel pathogène chez les personnes immunodéprimées. Ces personnes peuvent avoir un déficit génétique ou prendre des médicaments immunosuppresseurs, comme les patients ayant subi une transplantation qui prennent des médicaments pour que leur système immunitaire ne attaque pas et ne rejette pas le nouvel organe. 
Ces types d'infections sont appelés infections opportunistes. Rosowski se concentre explicitement sur l'aspergillose, la maladie causée par le champignon Aspergillus fumigatus. Aspergillus fumigatus vit dans notre environnement presque partout, principalement dans le sol, et fonctionne comme un décomposeur. Le microorganisme produit des spores pendant son cycle de vie reproductive. 
La recherche de Rosowski se concentre sur la compréhension de la première ligne de défense du système immunitaire contre ces spores pour déterminer ce qui ne va pas chez les individus immunodéprimés. Lorsque les gens sont infectés, Rosowski dit : "ces petites spores germent en hyphes, qui sont une croissance filamentaire. Cette croissance sécrète des enzymes qui dégradent vos tissus afin qu'elle puisse se développer dans vos tissus et à travers tout votre corps." 
Il existe des médicaments antifongiques qui peuvent freiner l'infection, mais 50 % des patients qui prennent ces médicaments meurent tout de même de la maladie. 
Rosowski utilise des poissons zèbres sous forme larvaire pour visualiser au microscope ce qui se passe dans les premières étapes de l'infection et comment des cellules spécifiques du système immunitaire réagissent au champignon. Rosowski et son équipe ont trouvé un récepteur particulier appelé Récepteur de type Toll 2 qui aide le système immunitaire à reconnaître et cibler les spores. 
"Le but à long terme est d'identifier les voies clés que votre système immunitaire inné sain utilise pour contrôler le champignon, puis de réfléchir à des moyens d'essayer de stimuler ces voies chez les personnes immunodéprimées," dit Rosowski. 
Le travail de Rosowski a le potentiel de conduire à un traitement qui empêcherait les infections de s'installer chez les individus immunodéprimés. 
Les aires de jeux aquatiques et les piscines sont des attractions populaires en été alors que les gens cherchent à se rafraîchir dans la chaleur écrasante. Mais cette eau peut apporter autre chose qu'un soulagement face aux hautes températures. 
Cryptosporidium est un microorganisme parasitaire qui cause des maladies diarrhéiques et peut persister dans l'eau pendant plus d'une semaine. Plus surprenant, il est résistant au chlore. 
Katelyn Walzer, professeure adjointe au Département de biologie, étudie Cryptosporidium — plus précisément Cryptosporidium parvum, qui infecte les bovins et les humains. Environ 70 % des veaux âgés de 1 à 3 semaines sont infectés par Cryptosporidium. L'infection se propage généralement chez les bovins par transmission fécale-orale. 
Chez les humains, le parasite présente le plus de risques pour les enfants malnutris et les personnes immunodéprimées. 
Historiquement, la cryptosporidiose a été une maladie peu étudiée. Elle est généralement sous-déclarée puisque la plupart des cas ne nécessitent pas d'hospitalisation. La plupart des cas nécessitant une intervention médicale se produisent dans des pays en développement qui n'ont pas toujours accès à de l'eau potable. 
Le parasite peut entraîner une malabsorption des nutriments, ce qui freine la croissance et empêche de guérir complètement

pt.title: Eles são minúsculos, estão em toda parte — e têm um grande impacto na saúde pública.
pt.description:
Eles não podem ser vistos a olho nu, mas os microorganismos estão por toda parte ao nosso redor. Enquanto a maioria é inofensiva e alguns são benéficos, outros podem nos deixar doentes. 

17 de setembro é o Dia Internacional do Microorganismo, marcando o dia em 1683 quando o cientista holandês Antonie van Leeuwenhoek enviou uma carta detalhando a primeira observação microscópica de um organismo unicelular que agora chamamos de bactéria. A carta descrevia “animalcules vivos” que van Leeuwenhoek coletou de sua própria boca e de outras pessoas.

Para comemorar o dia, estamos destacando três membros do corpo docente da Faculdade de Ciências da Universidade Clemson cuja pesquisa envolve microorganismos.

A maioria dos humanos inala esporos fúngicos diariamente. Pessoas com sistemas imunológicos saudáveis podem eliminar os esporos sem problemas, mas aquelas que estão imunocomprometidas são suscetíveis a infecções. 

Emily Rosowski, professora assistente no Departamento de Ciências Biológicas, estuda micróbios com potencial patogênico em pessoas imunocomprometidas. Essas pessoas podem ter uma deficiência genética ou tomar medicamentos imunossupressores, como os pacientes de transplante que tomam medicamentos para que seu sistema imunológico não ataque e rejeite o novo órgão. 

Esses tipos de infecções são chamados de infecções oportunistas. Rosowski foca explicitamente na aspergilose, a doença causada pelo fungo Aspergillus fumigatus. Aspergillus fumigatus vive em nosso ambiente em praticamente qualquer lugar, principalmente no solo, e funciona como um decompositor. O microorganismo produz esporos durante a fase de seu ciclo de vida reprodutivo. 

A pesquisa de Rosowski se concentra em entender a primeira linha de defesa do sistema imunológico contra esses esporos para determinar o que dá errado em indivíduos imunocomprometidos. Quando as pessoas são infectadas, Rosowski diz: “esses pequenos esporos germinam em hifas, que é um crescimento filamentoso. Esse crescimento secreta enzimas que degradam seus tecidos para que ele possa crescer em todo o seu corpo.” 

Existem medicamentos antifúngicos que podem conter a infecção, mas 50% dos pacientes que tomam esses medicamentos ainda morrem da doença. 

Rosowski usa zebrafish em sua forma larval para visualizar por meio de microscópio o que acontece nas primeiras fases da infecção e como células específicas do sistema imunológico reagem ao fungo. Rosowski e sua equipe encontraram um receptor específico chamado Receptor Tipo Toll 2 que ajuda o sistema imunológico a reconhecer e atacar os esporos. 

“O objetivo a longo prazo é identificar os caminhos-chave que seu sistema imunológico inato saudável usa para controlar o fungo e, em seguida, pensar em maneiras de tentar impulsionar esses caminhos em pessoas imunossuprimidas”, diz Rosowski. 

O trabalho de Rosowski tem o potencial de levar a um tratamento que impediria infecções de se estabelecerem em indivíduos imunocomprometidos. 

Parques aquáticos e piscinas são atrações populares no verão, enquanto as pessoas buscam se refrescar no calor escaldante. Mas essa água pode trazer algo além de alívio das altas temperaturas. 

Cryptosporidium é um microorganismo parasitário que causa doenças diarreicas e pode permanecer na água por mais de uma semana. Mais surpreendentemente, é resistente ao cloro. 

Katelyn Walzer, professora assistente no Departamento de Biologia, estuda Cryptosporidium — especificamente Cryptosporidium parvum, que infecta gado e humanos. Cerca de 70% dos bezerros de 1 a 3 semanas de idade estão infectados com Cryptosporidium. A infecção geralmente se espalha entre o gado por meio da transmissão fecal-oral. 

Em humanos, o parasita representa os maiores riscos para crianças desnutridas e imunocomprometidos. 

Historicamente, a criptosporidíase tem sido uma doença pouco estudada. Geralmente, é subnotificada, uma vez que a maioria dos casos não requer hospitalização. A maioria dos casos que requerem intervenção médica ocorre em países em desenvolvimento que nem sempre têm acesso a água potável. 

O parasita pode levar à má absorção de nutrientes, o que prejudica o crescimento e leva à incapacidade de se recuperar completamente da infecção. 

O parasita passa por uma forma dormente chamada oocisto, formando uma parede resiliente que lhe permite persistir na água sem um hospedeiro. Os humanos precisam ingerir apenas 10 oocistos para ficar doentes, mas um único episódio diarreico pode excretar milhões.

es.title: Son diminutos, están en todas partes y tienen un gran impacto en la salud pública.
es.description:
No se pueden ver a simple vista, pero los microorganismos están a nuestro alrededor. Mientras que la mayoría son inofensivos y algunos son beneficiosos, otros pueden enfermarnos. 
El 17 de septiembre es el Día Internacional de los Microorganismos, conmemorando el día en 1683 cuando el científico holandés Antonie van Leeuwenhoek envió una carta detallando la primera observación microscópica de un organismo unicelular que ahora llamamos bacterias. La carta describía "animalículos vivos" que van Leeuwenhoek recolectó de su propia boca y de la de otros. 
Para conmemorar el día, destacamos a tres miembros de la facultad del Colegio de Ciencias de la Universidad de Clemson cuya investigación involucra microorganismos. 
La mayoría de los humanos inhalan esporas fúngicas a diario. Las personas con sistemas inmunológicos saludables pueden eliminar las esporas sin problemas, pero aquellos que son inmunocomprometidos son susceptibles a infecciones. 
Emily Rosowski, profesora asistente en el Departamento de Ciencias Biológicas, estudia microorganismos con potencial patogénico en personas inmunocomprometidas. Estas personas pueden tener una deficiencia genética o tomar medicamentos inmunosupresores, como los pacientes de trasplante que toman medicación para que su sistema inmunológico no ataque y rechace el nuevo órgano. 
Estos tipos de infecciones se llaman infecciones oportunistas. Rosowski se enfoca explícitamente en la aspergilosis, la enfermedad causada por el hongo Aspergillus fumigatus. Aspergillus fumigatus vive en nuestro entorno prácticamente en cualquier lugar, principalmente en el suelo, y funciona como un descomponedor. El microorganismo produce esporas durante la etapa de su ciclo de vida reproductiva. 
La investigación de Rosowski se centra en comprender la primera línea de defensa del sistema inmunológico contra estas esporas para determinar qué sale mal en individuos inmunocomprometidos. Cuando las personas se infectan, Rosowski dice: "estas pequeñas esporas germinan en hifas, que son un crecimiento filamentoso. Ese crecimiento secreta enzimas que degradan tus tejidos para que pueda crecer a través de tus tejidos y por todo tu cuerpo". 
Existen medicamentos antifúngicos que pueden detener la infección, pero el 50% de los pacientes que toman estos medicamentos aún mueren a causa de la enfermedad. 
Rosowski utiliza peces cebra en su forma larval para visualizar a través de un microscopio lo que está sucediendo en las primeras etapas de la infección y cómo células específicas del sistema inmunológico reaccionan al hongo. Rosowski y su equipo han encontrado un receptor particular llamado Receptor tipo Toll 2 que ayuda al sistema inmunológico a reconocer y atacar las esporas. 
"El objetivo a largo plazo es identificar las vías clave que su sistema inmunológico innato saludable utiliza para controlar el hongo y luego pensar en maneras de intentar potenciar esas vías en personas inmunosuprimidas", dice Rosowski. 
El trabajo de Rosowski tiene el potencial de conducir a un tratamiento que prevenga que las infecciones se establezcan en individuos inmunocomprometidos. 
Las áreas de juegos acuáticos y las piscinas son atracciones populares en el verano, ya que las personas buscan mantenerse frescas en el calor abrasador. Pero esa agua puede traer algo más que alivio de las altas temperaturas. 
Cryptosporidium es un microorganismo parasitario que causa enfermedades diarreicas y puede permanecer en el agua durante más de una semana. Más sorprendentemente, es resistente al cloro. 
Katelyn Walzer, profesora asistente en el Departamento de Biología, estudia Cryptosporidium - específicamente Cryptosporidium parvum, que infecta a ganado y humanos. Aproximadamente el 70% de los terneros de 1 a 3 semanas están infectados con Cryptosporidium. La infección generalmente se propaga en el ganado a través de la transmisión fecal-oral. 
En los humanos, el parásito representa los mayores riesgos para los niños desnutridos y los inmunocomprometidos. 
Históricamente, la criptosporidiosis ha sido una enfermedad poco estudiada. Generalmente se informa menos, ya que la mayoría de los casos no requieren hospitalización. La mayoría de los casos que requieren intervención médica ocurren en países en desarrollo que no siempre tienen acceso a agua limpia. 
El parásito puede llevar a la mala absorción de nutrientes, lo que frena el crecimiento y lleva a la incapacidad de sanar completamente de la infección. 
El parásito pasa por una forma dormida llamada ooquiste, formando una pared resistente que le permite persistir en el agua sin un huésped. Los humanos necesitan ingerir solo 10 ooqu

title: HLA-G 14 bp polymorphism: Implications and its associated risk to malaria severity among iron-fortified Ghanaian infants and young children
description: Background of the studyMalaria is a paramount health concern mostly among infants and young children. The World Health Organization recommends iron fortification for children with iron deficiency anaemia living in malaria-endemic regions like Ghana. However, the intricate interplay between genetic polymorphisms and nutritional interventions in malaria susceptibility and severity remains unclear. The Human Leukocyte Antigen-G (HLA-G) locus within the Major Histocompatibility Complex (MHC) genes has surfaced as a critical player in regulating immune responses and influencing disease outcomes. Therefore, we aimed to evaluate the effect of HLA-G 14 bp polymorphism and its associated risk of malaria severity among Ghanaian infants and young children on iron fortification.MethodologyThis secondary double-blinded cluster randomized controlled trial involved 432 archival samples from the Tain District and Wenchi Municipal in the Bono Region. Participants aged between 6 and 36 months and consuming semi-solid foods were recruited in the study while children with malaria infection or other known medical conditions were excluded. Capillary blood samples were taken for anaemia determination using a haematology autoanalyzer, malaria infection status, and parasitaemia were assessed via microscopy, and HLA-G 14 bp polymorphism using PCR. Hardy-Weinberg equilibrium and multivariate regression models were used to analyze the data obtained.ResultsThe research findings indicate that among the iron-fortified children with HLA-G, 14 bp + /- and 14 bp-/- variants are likely to develop severe malaria. Also, the HLA-G 14 bp + /- variant was linked to a higher risk of anaemia development among participants who received iron supplements.ConclusionThe study results indicated that iron-fortified individuals carrying the HLA-G 14 bp insertion/deletion polymorphism have an elevated risk of developing severe malaria, which in turn predisposes them to anaemia.

title: Interplay of obesity and parasitic infection: current evidence of immunogenesis, tumorigenesis and leptin receptor involvement
description: BackgroundParasitic infections possess comparable risk factors to obesity. In addition, obesity impairs innate and adaptive immunity subsequently increasing vulnerability to infectious diseases.AimThe study investigated the leptin/leptin receptors, obesity-parasites mutual relationship and the effect of parasitic infections on immune metabolism, microbiota, and tumorigenesis in the context of obesity.MethodologyTo implement the current review, articles were gathered using the Egyptian Knowledge Bank (EKB), Web of Science, PubMed, and Google Scholar.ConclusionLeptin enhances anti-parasitic immunity. Obesity favors intestinal colonization of Blastocystis sp., Dientamoeba fragilis, Entamoeba coli, and Giardia intestinalis. Adipocytes act as a niche and a food source for Trypanosoma cruzi, Trypanosoma brucei, and Plasmodium. In addition, Toxoplasma gondii relies on the circulatory cholesterol to thrive. Obesity provokes low-grade chronic inflammation and metabolic syndrome. Yet, Nippostrongylus brasiliensis and Fasciola hepatica attempted to alleviate inflammation and metabolic syndrome. Hookworm improves insulin resistance. However, parasites such as Schistosoma mansoni, Trichuris suis, Taenia pisiformis, Entamoeba histolytica, Trypanosoma cruzi, and Trypanosoma brucei, and Toxoplasma aggravated metabolic immune metabolic syndrome. Obesity hampered immunity against Leishmania sp.. and Plasmodium sp. is diabetogenic. Giardia infection and Heligmosoides polygyrus infections induce dysbiosis in obesity. Obesity and parasites like Trichomonas vaginalis, S. haematobium, S. mansoni, Clonorchis sinensis, Opishorchis viverrini showed similar cancer types. Yet, Toxoplasma gondii and Echinococcus granulosus have anti-tumorigenic effects. Obesity/high-fat diet hinders Schistosoma mansoni, Trichuris muris, and Entamoeba histolytica infections. Also, Blastocystis sp., Dientamoeba fragilis, Giardia intestinalis, Trichinella spiralis, and Schistosoma appeared to have ameliorative effects in obesity.

title: It is time to increase Africa’s governmental representation on the governing board of the global fund to fight AIDS, tuberculosis and malaria
Bearing witness to the harm caused by Trump clawing back billions in foreign aid
description: Nicholas Kristof, Pulitzer Prize-winning columnist for the New York Times, says the Trump administration has created “waste and inefficiency” through dismantling USAID, the exact opposite of its intended goal. “I'm just back from East Africa,” he said. “And what I saw was children dying all over from these preventable diseases, of malaria, of infections, of malnutrition.” He points out that when we let things like this fester abroad, they will inevitably become an issue within the U.S., where it’s exponentially more expensive to treat. He uses tuberculous as an example, a disease fairly inexpensive to treat abroad, yet it can cost up to a half million dollars to treat a single antibiotic resistant case in the U.S.

Il prend la tuberculose comme exemple, une maladie relativement peu coûteuse à traiter à l'étranger, mais qui peut coûter jusqu'à un demi-million de dollars pour traiter un seul cas résistant aux antibiotiques aux États-Unis.

"Acabei de voltar da África Oriental", disse ele. "E o que vi foram crianças morrendo por toda parte devido a essas doenças evitáveis, como malária, infecções e desnutrição." Ele aponta que quando deixamos essas questões se agravar no exterior, elas inevitavelmente se tornarão um problema dentro dos EUA, onde o tratamento é exponencialmente mais caro. Ele usa a tuberculose como exemplo, uma doença relativamente barata de tratar no exterior, mas que pode custar até meio milhão de dólares para tratar um único caso resistente a antibióticos nos EUA.

"Acabo de regresar de África Oriental", dijo. "Y lo que vi fue a niños muriendo por todas partes debido a estas enfermedades prevenibles, como la malaria, infecciones y desnutrición." title: The Role of Mathematical Modelling in Predicting and Controlling Infectious Disease Outbreaks in Underserved Settings: A Systematic Review and Meta‐Analysis
description: ABSTRACTBackground and AimMathematical modelling plays an important role in public health by enabling the prediction of disease outbreaks, assessment of transmission dynamics and evaluation of intervention strategies. Although widely applied in high‐resource settings, its use in underserved contexts remains underexplored. This review aimed to examine and synthesize current evidence on the application of mathematical modelling for predicting and controlling infectious diseases in underserved settings.MethodsA comprehensive and reproducible search was conducted using Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta‐Analyses (PRISMA) and population, intervention, comparison and outcome (PICO) frameworks across databases, including PubMed, Scopus, Medline, ScienceDirect and EBSCOhost. Keywords and Medical Subject Headings (MeSH) terms related to mathematical modelling and infectious disease control were applied. Two reviewers independently screened titles, abstracts and full texts, with a third resolving discrepancies. Thematic analysis and meta‐analysis were used for synthesis.ResultsOut of 838 studies screened, 27 (3.2%) met inclusion criteria. Deterministic models were most used, followed by stochastic and agent‐based models. Diseases modelled included COVID‐19, malaria, tuberculosis (TB), Ebola, Zika, chikungunya, dengue, diphtheria, respiratory infections, visceral leishmaniasis (VL) and Mpox. Modelling predicted the impact of interventions on transmission, with pooled effect size (Ro) of 1.32 (θ = 1.3, p < 0.0001). However, challenges, such as data underreporting, gaps and inconsistencies, were common, potentially affecting model accuracy and real‐world applicability.ConclusionMathematical modelling has demonstrated value in supporting infectious disease control in underserved settings. However, the predominance of deterministic models limits adaptability across diverse contexts. Poor data quality further constrains reliability. Future work should focus on expanding modelling approaches, strengthening data infrastructure and addressing a broader range of diseases. These findings can guide public health policy by supporting data‐driven decision‐making, improving resource allocation and integrating modelling into outbreak preparedness and response strategies in underserved settings.
